facts.text: The case is Criminal Appeal No. 79 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 18, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 947 of 1959.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on May 3, 1962 by DAS GUPTA, J.

facts.text: The High Court at Allahabad dismissed the application for revision of an order under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is against the order of the High Court at Allahabad dismissing the application for revision of an order under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: The three appellants carry on the trade of auctioning vegetables.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants carry on the trade of auctioning vegetables.

facts.text: Vegetables are brought in carts which are parked on the public road outside the building where the auctioning takes place.

anchor.surface_text: These vegetables, it appears, are brought in carts which are parked on the public road outside the building where the auctioning takes place.

facts.text: There was some dispute between the appellants and the Municipal Board.

facts.text: A Magistrate passed an order under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure against the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Section 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure empowers action by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate or Magistrate Ist class

concepts.interpretation: Empowers specified Magistrates to remove public nuisances in certain circumstances, including unlawful obstruction or nuisance on public ways and conduct of trade injurious to health or physical comfort.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to remove public nuisances in certain circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The first clause provides for action by Magistrate where he considers, on receiving a police-report or other information and on taking such evidence as he thinks fit, that any unlawful obstruction or nuisance should be removed from any way, river or channel which is or may be lawfully used by the public or from any public place.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to removal of unlawful obstruction or nuisance from public ways; appellants not causing the obstruction by carts parked by others.

concepts.unlisted_description: Unlawful obstruction or nuisance on public way, river, channel or public place

anchor.surface_text: The second clause deals with the position where the conduct of any trade or occupation or the keeping of any goods or merchandise, is injurious to the health or physical comfort of the community and that in consequence such trade or occupation should be prohibited or regulated or such goods or merchandise should be removed or the keeping thereof regulated.

concepts.interpretation: Auctioning vegetables causing noise is not injurious to health or physical comfort of community; some discomfort from necessary trades in city localities does not justify prohibition.

concepts.unlisted_label: Injurious to Health or Physical Comfort
concepts.unlisted_description: Test under Section 133(2) CrPC for prohibiting trade

issues.text: The real question is, whether because this trade of auctioning vegetables which the appellants carry on in their private house produce the consequence that people passing by the road are put to inconvenience, action can be taken under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The real question is, whether because this trade of auctioning vegetables which the appellants carry on in their private house produce the companysequence that people passing by the road are put to inconvenience, action can be taken under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

issues.text: Whether the first clause of s. 133 CrPC applies, i.e., whether there is any unlawful obstruction or nuisance caused by the appellants that should be removed from the public way.

anchor.surface_text: The first clause provides for action by Magistrate where he considers, on receiving a police-report or other information and on taking such evidence as he thinks fit, that any unlawful obstruction or nuisance should be removed from any way, river or channel which is or may be lawfully used by the public or from any public place.

issues.text: Turning now to the next clause, the question arises how the conduct of this auctioning trade is injurious to the health or physical comfort of the community.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the, next clause, the question arises how the companyduct of this auctioning trade is injurious to the health or physical companyfort of the companymunity.

arguments.claim: The Municipal Board was behind the move to get the order under s. 133 passed against the appellants due to a prior dispute

anchor.surface_text: There was some dispute between these appellants and the Municipal Board which it is suggested by the appellants was really behind the move to get this order under s. 133 passed against them.

arguments.qualifiers: it is suggested by the appellants

court_response_anchor.surface_text: al Board which it is suggested by the appellan

arguments.court_reasoning: It is unnecessary, however, for us to consider that matter.

arguments.claim: When it is clear that the business of auctioning vegetables cannot be carried on without causing obstruction to the passers by, the conduct of the business can be prohibited even though it is carried on in a private house

anchor.surface_text: The High Court seems to be of the opinion- when it is clear that the business of auctioning vegetables cannot be carried on without causing obstruction to the passers by, the conduct of the business can be prohibited, even though it if carried on in a private

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of Criminal Procedure. The High Court seems to be of the opinion- when it is clear that the business of auctioning vegetables cannot be carried on wit

arguments.court_reasoning: It seems to us that this proposition has been put too widely.

arguments.claim: The first clause of s. 133 CrPC does not apply as the appellants cannot be considered the persons causing any unlawful obstruction

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to see how the first clause can have any application. Unlawful obstruction, if any, is certainly not caused by the people who carry on the trade of auctioning. If the obstruction caused by keeping the carts on the road can be considered to be unlawful obstruction within the meaning of this clause드bout which we express no opinion드ction can be taken against the persons causing such obstruction.

arguments.claim: The second clause of s. 133 CrPC does not apply as the conduct of auctioning vegetables is not injurious to the health or physical comfort of the community

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the next clause, the question arises how the conduct of this auctioning trade is injurious to the health or physical comfort of the community. Undoubtedly, some amount of noise and perhaps, a great deal of noise is caused when the auction is going on. That however is a necessary concomitant of buying and selling large quantities and it will be unreasonable to think that merely because, some amount of noise is caused which people preferring perfect peace may not like, this is injurious to the physical comfort, or health of the community.

arguments.qualifiers: appears to us, in our opinion

holdings.text: It is difficult to see how the first clause can have any application. Unlawful obstruction, if any, is certainly not caused by the people who carry on the trade of auctioning... In our opinion, the appellants cannot be considered to be the persons causing obstruction.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to see how the first clause can have any application. Unlawful obstruction, if any, is certainly not caused by the people who carry on the trade of auctioning. If the obstruction caused by keeping the carts on the road can be considered to be unlawful obstruction within the meaning of this clause드bout which we express no opinion드ction can be taken against the persons causing such obstruction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants conduct auction inside private house; carts parked by varying third parties who bring vegetables; appellants not causing the obstruction.

holdings.text: It will be unreasonable to think that merely because some amount of noise is caused which people preferring perfect peace may not like, this is injurious to the physical comfort, or health of the community.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, some amount of noise and perhaps, a great deal of noise is caused when the auction is going on. That however is a necessary concomitant of buying and selling large quantities and it will be unreasonable to think that merely because, some amount of noise is caused which people preferring perfect peace may not like, this is injurious to the physical comfort, or health of the community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Noise from auctioning vegetables is necessary for buying/selling; such discomfort from beneficial trades in city localities does not amount to injury to health or physical comfort warranting prohibition.

holdings.text: The slight discomfort that may be caused to some people passing by the road or living in the neighbourhood cannot ordinarily be considered to be such as to justify action under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. We do not think that the orders are justified under s. 133.

anchor.surface_text: action under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. We do not think that the orders are justified under s. 133. In our opinion therefore, the slight discomfort that may be caused to some people passing by the road or living in the neighbourhood cannot ordinarily be considered to be such as to justify action under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Neither clause one nor clause two of S.133 applies; no public nuisance as defined justifying removal or prohibition.

holdings.text: It seems to us that this proposition has been put too widely.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that this proposition has been put too widely. Section 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure empowers action by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate or Magistrate Ist class to remove public nuisances in certain circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's view that any business inevitably causing obstruction can be prohibited even from private house overlooks specific requirements of S.133 clauses.

holdings.text: If the obstruction caused by keeping the carts on the road can be considered to be unlawful obstruction within the meaning of this clause드bout which we express no opinion드ction can be taken against the persons causing such obstruction.

anchor.surface_text: The obvious difficulty in the way of that might be that the persons who bring the carts are not the same from day to day. But whether or not any action is possible under s. 133 against the persons bringing the carts, we are unable to agree

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical application to actual obstructors possible, but not opined on; not attributing to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore, the slight discomfort that may be caused to some people passing by the road or living in the neighbourhood cannot ordinarily be companysidered to be such as to justify action under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. We do number think that the orders are justified under s. 133.

outcome.relief_summary: Orders under s. 133 of the Code of Criminal Procedure held not justified
